sources: Malliaras P. et al., 2015. Patellar Tendinopathy: Clinical Diagnosis, Load Management, and Rehabilitation

chunks.text: Anterior knee pain localized to the proximal patellar tendon, aggravated by jumping, deceleration, and deep knee flexion under load.
Symptoms are strongly load-related; pain may warm up with activity but increase after high-load sessions.
Decline squat commonly reproduces pain at the inferior patellar pole; single-leg squat may be provocative near end range.
Point tenderness at the proximal patellar tendon is typical; effusion is usually absent.
Imaging is not required for diagnosis; ultrasound/MRI can show thickening or hypoechoic changes but clinical picture guides care.
Education: manage cumulative load; symptoms reflect tendon load tolerance. Emphasize warm-up and gradual progression.
Initial management often includes isometric quadriceps loading for analgesia (e.g., 5 x 45s holds), then progress to heavy slow resistance.
Guardrail: avoid early high-volume plyometrics and deep loaded knee flexion; reintroduce gradually per pain guidelines.
Return-to-sport: progress from isometrics to isotonic heavy slow resistance, then energy-storage loading before full plyometrics.

Ground truth (faculty): Primary working diagnosis is patellar tendinopathy. Key positives: localized inferior pole tenderness, pain with decline squat/single-leg squat, load-related symptoms; Key negatives: no true instability, minimal/no effusion. Use for grading only; do not expose to students.
